name: sfchronicle
text: With the pandemic surging across the country, more and more communities are keeping watch for the virus in wastewater. https://t.co/ozA7DbyCfy

name: sfchronicle
text:
.@SanJoseStateFB coach Alonzo Carter hosts a biweekly Zoom call that routinely draws hundreds of Black coaches from around the country to network, discuss systemic racism and progression in their sport.

@annkillion has more: https://t.co/HuvzdC6DN7

name: sfchronicle
text:
The coronavirus has now infected more than 40,000 people in the Bay Area, a region once credited with taking aggressive, early action to stem the spread of the virus. As of Friday, there were 40,068 total cases.

See the latest data on our Virus Tracker: https://t.co/L8LLxjvFF5

name: sfchronicle
text: “The leaderboards are going to look weird. ...  You can expect really weird teams in the playoffs as well. It takes only a strong 60-game stretch to get in.” https://t.co/6F6MuOOPkM

name: sfchronicle
text: "At least we can take heart that it's true, for now at least, that if you live in San Francisco and test positive, there's still a paycheck for you." https://t.co/p29gvrJ7UE

name: sfchronicle
text: Marin County will decide whether to fine people who violate shelter-in-place health orders, officials said. The Board of Supervisors will take up the issue, including fines for businesses that are not supposed to be open, group gatherings and parties. https://t.co/l8gvzRrVsD

name: sfchronicle
text:
Embattled East Bay priest Varghese “George” Alengadan has been charged with sexual battery against a woman from his time as pastor of St. Joseph Basilica in Alameda.

https://t.co/bH1PdZd06X

name: sfchronicle
text: Scientists hope that human excrement can help guide health policy today, telling them where the novel coronavirus emerges, what areas should receive medical supplies or be locked down, and when it may be safe to reopen communities. https://t.co/dNZjEUOLP4

name: sfchronicle
text:
Several Mid-Market residents and businesses have sued the city of San Francisco over negligence, alleging the city facilitated an unsafe environment on the streets. 
https://t.co/x4O1wYdYei

name: sfchronicle
text: The long-anticipated live album and concert film documenting Metallica’s second collaboration with the @sfsymphony is set for release on Aug. 28. https://t.co/Z1zxfyX1ja

name: sfchronicle
text: State health officials reported an uptick in coronavirus cases among staff and residents in skilled nursing facilities: 74 health care workers and 2,318 residents at 1,223 facilities are infected. https://t.co/bvzLSK9GO9

name: sfchronicle
text:
The Giants regulars fighting injuries — Pence, Longoria and Belt — had a relatively good Friday. Manager Gabe Kapler would not rule any of them out for Thursday's season opener in Los Angeles.

https://t.co/ovO7sQMMvI

name: sfchronicle
text: “Waning antibodies affect vaccine development,” said the chief of science at S.F.’s California Academy of Sciences. “Where natural immunity doesn’t really develop or last, then vaccine programs are not likely to be easily successful or achievable.” https://t.co/yOoVoVVB7S

name: sfchronicle
text:
More than 100 inmates at Santa Rita Jail are infected with coronavirus after it spread unseen from bunk-to-bunk and cell-to-cell in the past two days, marking the jail’s largest outbreak since the pandemic began.

https://t.co/VYbnGsto6e

name: sfchronicle
text: Permanent immunity to the coronavirus may not be possible: Recent studies indicate that the human body does not retain antibodies, meaning vaccine hopes could fade. https://t.co/3QRbQcBfQF

name: sfchronicle
text:
90s cult game show "Supermarket Sweep" is now streaming on @netflix, and @hooleil talks about why it's the ultimate anti-food food show worth watching right now.

"It's kind of feminist... if you squint," she writes. https://t.co/X7QkoCkDsc

name: sfchronicle
text: BREAKING: Rep. John Lewis, a lion of the civil rights movement who went on to a long and celebrated career in Congress, has died. He was 80.  https://t.co/1X4QSFGwal

name: sfchronicle
text:
Several businesses in San Francisco have permanently closed since the Bay Area’s shelter-in-place orders began on March 17. 

Which COVID-related closure has you most upset?

https://t.co/Lk7VQVujBZ

name: sfchronicle
text:
Last month, @MickLaSalle
reviewed the documentary about Rep. John Lewis from S.F. filmmaker Dawn Porter. 

"If he sits in a cushy chair and hangs out with his cats for the rest of his life, he’ll still be remembered as a great man."

https://t.co/v7B2BTZBxa

name: sfchronicle
text: BREAKING: California DOJ will investigate the Vallejo Police Department's disposal of key evidence in the killing of Sean Monterrosa — the windshield of the unmarked police vehicle an officer shot through. https://t.co/63HLB24svy

name: sfchronicle
text: The deepening scandal has been held up as an emblem of a long-derided culture of casual corruption in San Francisco City Hall. https://t.co/ERvAm5SYYj

name: sfchronicle
text: Before "Hamilton," Lin-Manuel Miranda (@Lin_Manuel) and his crew knew only that they loved being together, they loved creating together, and that their new act, Freestyle Love Supreme, let them invite the whole world into their joy. https://t.co/CqfpxMuquc

name: sfchronicle
text: When Mitt Romney was 17 years old, he came to San Francisco for the 1964 GOP Convention and watched his father George Romney suffer a bitter defeat. The event helps explain why Mitt Romney marched in a Black Lives Matter demonstration. https://t.co/Cc0l3tw4Y2

name: sfchronicle
text: Bounty columnist Christian Reynoso (@xtianreynoso) says his Olive Oil-Poached Early Girl Tomatoes are "transformative" and "might even make you question why you’ve ever cooked a tomato any other way." Check out the recipe here: https://t.co/A6fASw2PWh.

name: sfchronicle
text: 16-year-old Lupita Martinez is a charter member of the Oakland-born Radical Monarchs, an alternative to the Girl Scouts focusing on empowering girls of color. Now, they're featured in the PBS documentary “We Are the Radical Monarchs."  https://t.co/8rFjY630CA

name: sfchronicle
text: When the protests over the killing of George Floyd reached the Bay Area, students lead some of the biggest demonstrations. Here’s what the youth leaders of today have to say about why they marched: https://t.co/VqzwXZCrCu

name: sfchronicle
text: When Mitt Romney was 17, he came to San Francisco for the 1964 GOP Convention and watched his father suffer a bitter defeat to anti-civil rights candidate Barry Goldwater. The event helps explain why Romney marched in a Black Lives Matter demonstration: https://t.co/00JA6i4GEh

name: sfchronicle
text: “This is about helping us to survive,” Manny Yekutiel said. “I wish I didn’t have to say that, but it’s about survival now. And all we have to work with is outdoor space.” https://t.co/1qtjAn9JR0

name: sfchronicle
text:
Why "Supermarket Sweep" is worth watching right now, per @hooleil:

- It's kind of feminist if you squint
- It turned the grocery store into the Thunderdome
- Capitalism so obvious it’s funny
- It's a food show without pretension or preciousness

https://t.co/yRdh7JkoZ8

name: sfchronicle
text:
With teams required to practice physical distancing in dugouts and bullpens during games, @Athletics have installed tents in the stands behind each dugout and bullpen at the Coliseum to serve as auxiliary seating for players and personnel.

https://t.co/nU6nZHJIoX

name: sfchronicle
text: Several businesses in S.F. have permanently closed since the Bay Area’s shelter-in-place orders began. On the roster: Louis’ Restaurant, Toy Boat Dessert Cafe, and Ver Unica. Which spot will you miss the most? https://t.co/kJzc6cKvBA

name: sfchronicle
text: Bucket Bar, like so much of 2020, is temporary. “I know I’m going to remember this time very fondly.” https://t.co/Ga5ZbWeGY3

name: sfchronicle
text: Jason Kelly Johnson and Nataly Gattegno have designed the office tower of the future. Meet Supergalaxy, a windowless and wall-less environment that might be the key to a post-pandemic workspace. https://t.co/8GEX8dqHWe

name: sfchronicle
text: For the latest updates on wildfires burning across California, use our interactive Fire Tracker: https://t.co/SBs1ChkN7e

name: sfchronicle
text: "Think of them as caviar, but tomatoes," writes columnist Christian Reynoso (@xtianreynoso) of his Olive Oil-Poached Early Girl Tomatoes. Showstopping, jewel-like red spheres are poached and simmered with olive oil, garlic, and orange: https://t.co/NdwXBsjQgl

name: sfchronicle
text:
S.F. Green Fest becomes the first Bay Area film festival to publicly announce its permanent closure. Other film festivals are trying to ride out the pandemic, but share a similar state of concern.
https://t.co/1u0jUI1FXI

name: sfchronicle
text:
Every editor hopes the books they work on will have longevity, but Alan Rinzler, the longtime editor of Hunter S. Thompson, couldn't have predicted how 'Fear and Loathing on the Campaign Trail '72' would align with current events.

https://t.co/PqnUYQdIER

name: sfchronicle
text:
If you have sloppy handwriting in California, your mail ballot could get tossed. More than 14,000 mail ballots were rejected in the primary because the signature on the vote-by-mail envelope didn’t match the one on the voter registration card.

https://t.co/S0mTtIPYs9

name: sfchronicle
text: Olive Oil-Poached Early Girl Tomatoes are the answer to all your food needs. They can be substituted for raw tomatoes in a salad, heated up and tossed in an herb-forward pasta dish, or spread on your lunchtime BLT, writes @xtianreynoso. https://t.co/5WRr3QMyN9
